title: Nature's fortress: How cacti keep water in and predators out - Lucas C. Majure

multiple-choice.question: What is a primary function of the spines of a cactus?

options.label: B
options.text: To limit water loss by reducing surface area

multiple-choice.question: What type of leaf modification do cacti have to adapt to desert environments?

options.label: A
options.text: Large, flat leaves to absorb sunlight

options.label: B
options.text: Thin, needle-like leaves to reduce water loss

options.label: C
options.text: Highly modified leaves that form spines

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of the waxy substance called a cuticle on a cactus's skin?

options.label: A
options.text: To protect the plant from extreme temperatures

multiple-choice.question: When do the stomata on a cactus typically open?

options.label: A
options.text: During the hottest part of the day

options.label: B
options.text: At night when temperatures are lower

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the roots of the Saguaro cactus?

options.label: A
options.text: They are extremely deep, reaching up to 10 meters

options.label: B
options.text: They are very shallow, with most only a few inches deep

options.label: C
options.text: They are nonexistent, with the plant relying on other means for water

options.label: D
options.text: They are only present during periods of rainfall

multiple-choice.question: How do the lateral roots of the Saguaro cactus respond to rainfall?

options.label: A
options.text: They shrink and become less active

options.label: C
options.text: They rapidly grow and spread to take up available water

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the mucilage in the cells of a cactus?

options.label: B
options.text: To protect the plant from extreme temperatures

options.label: C
options.text: To cling to water molecules and prevent evaporation

multiple-choice.question: In what type of environment can the mistletoe cactus be found?
Why is it difficult for the mistletoe cactus to obtain water in its environment?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the rainforest is too dry

options.label: B
options.text: Because the cactus is too small

options.label: C
options.text: Because there's nowhere for its roots to go

options.label: D
options.text: Because the cactus is too sensitive to sunlight

multiple-choice.question: What allows cacti to thrive in environments with limited water availability?

options.label: A
options.text: Their ability to produce a lot of seeds

options.label: C
options.text: Their adaptations to limit water loss and take advantage of available water

options.label: D
options.text: Their ability to migrate to areas with more water

title: The surprisingly long history of electric cars - Daniel Sperling and Gil Tal

multiple-choice.question: What were the three major options for buying a car in 1899?

options.label: B
options.text: Steam-powered, gasoline, and battery-powered electric vehicle

options.label: D
options.text: Internal combustion, external combustion, and battery-powered

multiple-choice.question: What was a major disadvantage of steam-powered cars in 1899?

options.label: B
options.text: They required extra water to refuel and had a long engine heat-up time

options.label: D
options.text: They had a short driving range

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of American cars were electric by the end of the 19th century?
Who was one of the inventors that tried to build batteries that stored more electricity for early electric vehicles?

options.label: B
options.text: The low efficiency of internal combustion engines

options.label: C
options.text: The high price of electric vehicles and the low price of gasoline

options.label: D
options.text: The lack of access to electricity

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the car model released by Ford in 1908 that captured the public imagination?
What type of batteries were developed in the 1990s that helped spark a new wave of electric vehicles?
What was the name of the car company that released the lithium-ion-powered Roadster in 2008?
What is expected to happen to gas-powered vehicles as governments focus on slowing climate change?

options.label: C
options.text: They will be replaced by electric vehicles

options.label: D
options.text: They will be phased out gradually

title: Where will you be able to live in 20 years? - Carol Farbotko and Ingrid Boas

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason for the changing landscape in Mohammadpur?

options.label: B
options.text: Sediment carried by rivers and storms

multiple-choice.question: What has happened to the Meghna River coastline since 2000?

options.label: C
options.text: It has overtaken the coastline by 2.5 kilometers

options.label: D
options.text: It has become a popular tourist destination

multiple-choice.question: What is a common impact of extreme weather events on coastal communities?

options.label: C
options.text: Displacement of people from their homes

multiple-choice.question: What is a major factor contributing to the rise in extreme weather events?
Which country has a unique combination of low-lying geography and heavily populated coastal regions?
What adaptation strategy have some residents of Mohammadpur employed to cope with flooding?

options.label: A
options.text: Building more resilient homes on higher ground or elevated stilts

options.label: D
options.text: Buying land on newly emerging islands in the delta

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult for some residents of low-lying Pacific Island nations to adapt to climate change?

options.label: C
options.text: Insufficient land area to move inland

multiple-choice.question: What measure have the governments and citizens of Kiribati and Tuvalu taken to fortify their countries against climate change?

options.label: B
options.text: Planting coastal mangrove forests and building up low-lying areas of land with dredged sand

multiple-choice.question: What is a major challenge in addressing climate mobility?

options.label: C
options.text: Difficulty in measuring and defining the phenomenon

multiple-choice.question: Why is it essential to listen to those on the front lines of the climate crisis?

options.label: A
options.text: To raise awareness about climate change

options.label: D
options.text: To understand the diverse experiences of affected communities

title: 2 questions to uncover your passion — and turn it into a career - Noeline Kirabo

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's dilemma six years ago?

options.label: A
options.text: Deciding which job to take after graduating

options.label: B
options.text: Choosing between pursuing a passion or staying in a comfortable job

options.label: C
options.text: Figuring out how to make more money

options.label: D
options.text: Deciding whether to go back to school

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is a common notion about finding one's passion?

options.label: A
options.text: It's something that only the young can do

options.label: B
options.text: It's a luxury that only the rich can enjoy

options.label: C
options.text: It's something that can be found through education

options.label: D
options.text: It's something that can be found through travel

multiple-choice.question: What did the speaker decide to do after quitting their job?

options.label: A
options.text: Sign up for a course at a vocational institution

multiple-choice.question: What did the speaker discover about the education system?

options.label: A
options.text: It's designed to help people find their passion

options.label: B
options.text: It's designed to provide people with a wide range of options

options.label: C
options.text: It's designed around preselected options that young people are expected to fit in

options.label: D
options.text: It's designed to prepare people for retirement

multiple-choice.question: How did the speaker build their CV and get into employment?
What is the name of the organization founded by the speaker?
According to the speaker, what is passion?

options.label: B
options.text: A collection of life experiences that give one a deep sense of fulfillment

multiple-choice.question: What are the two reflective questions asked by the speaker to help people identify their passion?

options.label: A
options.text: What do you want to achieve in life? What makes you happy?

options.label: B
options.text: If you had all the time and money in the world, what would you do? What makes you happy or gives you a deep sense of fulfillment?

options.label: C
options.text: What are your strengths and weaknesses? What do you want to do with your life?

options.label: D
options.text: What do you value most in life? What do you want to achieve in the next 5 years?

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is necessary for passion to become a career?
What is the outcome for the young people who have gone through the speaker's program?

options.label: B
options.text: They have all started their own businesses

options.label: C
options.text: They have been able to turn their ideas and burning desires into profitable businesses or social enterprises

options.label: D
options.text: They have all gone back to school

title: How the COVID-19 vaccines were created so quickly - Kaitlyn Sadtler and Elizabeth Wayne

multiple-choice.question: How long did it take for COVID-19 vaccines to clear the threshold for emergency use?
What is the key ingredient in mRNA vaccines?
What is the function of the ribosome in the cell?

options.label: B
options.text: To translate and follow mRNA instructions to build proteins

options.label: C
options.text: To inject nanoparticles into the cell

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of encoding trillions of mRNA molecules with the instructions for a specific viral protein?

options.label: A
options.text: To introduce the body to a live virus

options.label: B
options.text: To safely introduce the body to a virus and train the immune response

multiple-choice.question: What is the nanoparticle in mRNA vaccines made of?
Why is the vaccine kept at a temperature of -20 to -80 degrees Celsius?

options.label: A
options.text: To ensure the components break down

options.label: B
options.text: To ensure none of the components break down

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the mRNA molecule once it is inside the cell?

options.label: B
options.text: It is destroyed by the cell

options.label: C
options.text: The ribosome translates its instructions and begins assembling the viral protein

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the immune system being activated by the vaccine?

options.label: C
options.text: The body produces antibodies to fight the viral protein

multiple-choice.question: What is an advantage of mRNA vaccines over traditional vaccines?

options.label: A
options.text: They contain weakened versions of live viruses

options.label: B
options.text: They require time-intensive research to prepare

options.label: C
options.text: They don't actually contain any viral particles

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential benefit of mRNA vaccines in the fight against disease?

options.label: A
options.text: They can only treat one disease

options.label: B
options.text: They can treat any disease by swapping out a single component

options.label: C
options.text: They are only effective against COVID-19

options.label: D
options.text: They are only effective against viral diseases

title: The secret society of the Great Dismal Swamp - Dan Sayers

multiple-choice.question: Where is the Great Dismal Swamp located?

options.label: C
options.text: Straddling North Carolina and South Carolina

multiple-choice.question: What year did the first systematic archaeological foray into the Great Dismal Swamp take place?

options.label: A
options.text: The largest Indigenous American settlement in North America

options.label: B
options.text: The largest Maroon settlement in all of North America

options.label: C
options.text: The largest European settlement in North America

options.label: D
options.text: The largest enslaved worker settlement in North America

multiple-choice.question: Why did the Swamp communities have to be largely self-sufficient?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they were too far from the outside world

options.label: B
options.text: Because their success and survival depended on staying hidden from the outside world

options.label: C
options.text: Because they had no access to resources

multiple-choice.question: What type of objects were likely left by ancient Indigenous people and reused and modified by others later on?
What event likely led to the dispersal of the secret Swamp communities?
What was the approximate time period during which many people lived in the hidden settlements of the Great Dismal Swamp?
Who fostered a refuge in the Great Dismal Swamp to resist slavery and colonization?

options.label: C
options.text: Generations of Black Maroons and Indigenous Americans

multiple-choice.question: What does the Great Dismal Swamp offer today?

options.label: A
options.text: A complete record of the secret, self-reliant world

options.label: B
options.text: A partial record of the secret, self-reliant world

options.label: C
options.text: No record of the secret, self-reliant world

options.label: D
options.text: A record of the outside world

title: A woman's fury holds lifetimes of wisdom - Tracee Ellis Ross

multiple-choice.question: The speaker's friend was moved out of the way by a stranger at the post office, which triggered a strong emotional response. What was this emotional response?
According to the speaker, what is the common thread between seemingly innocuous and horrific situations of men helping themselves to women's bodies?

options.label: B
options.text: The level of physical harm caused

options.label: C
options.text: The spectrum of behaviors that make space for the horrific

options.label: D
options.text: The reaction of the women involved

multiple-choice.question: The speaker uses an analogy of someone taking a cell phone out of someone's hand to illustrate what point?

options.label: A
options.text: That men are more likely to be victims of theft

options.label: B
options.text: That women are more likely to be victims of harassment

options.label: C
options.text: That men helping themselves to women's bodies is a normalized behavior

options.label: D
options.text: That women should be more careful with their belongings

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, why do men often help themselves to women's bodies without consent?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are fundamentally less moral

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are socialized to believe they have the right to do so

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are trying to assert power over women

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not aware of the impact of their actions

multiple-choice.question: The speaker mentions that women have been trained to think that they are overreacting or being too sensitive when they express anger or frustration. What is the result of this training?

options.label: A
options.text: Women become more confident in expressing their emotions

options.label: B
options.text: Women learn to suppress their emotions and rationalize the behavior of others

options.label: C
options.text: Women become more aggressive in asserting their rights

options.label: D
options.text: Women become less empathetic towards others

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the significance of the fury that women feel in response to men helping themselves to their bodies?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a sign of weakness and lack of control

options.label: B
options.text: It is a natural response to a perceived threat

options.label: C
options.text: It holds centuries of never being able to directly address or express indignation, frustration, and rage

options.label: D
options.text: It is a sign of overreacting and being too sensitive

multiple-choice.question: The speaker calls on men to be allies in the movement towards women's equality. What does she encourage men to do?

options.label: A
options.text: Take charge and lead the movement

options.label: B
options.text: Be accountable, self-reflective, compassionate, and open

options.label: C
options.text: Ignore the issue and let women handle it

options.label: D
options.text: Become more aggressive in asserting their rights

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message to women regarding their fury?

options.label: A
options.text: To suppress it and rationalize the behavior of others

options.label: B
options.text: To acknowledge it, give it language, and share it in safe places

options.label: C
options.text: To be afraid of it and hide it

options.label: D
options.text: To use it as a justification for aggressive behavior

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the significance of the current moment in the movement towards women's equality?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a time of setback and regression

options.label: B
options.text: It is a time of stagnation and lack of progress

options.label: C
options.text: It is a time of shift and change, where the global collection of women's experiences can no longer be ignored

options.label: D
options.text: It is a time of celebration and complacency

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's final message to the audience?

options.label: A
options.text: To continue ignoring the issue of men helping themselves to women's bodies

options.label: B
options.text: To take action and work towards change

options.label: C
options.text: To be patient and wait for someone else to solve the problem

options.label: D
options.text: To give up and accept the status quo

title: How do you know what's true? - Sheila Marie Orfano

multiple-choice.question: Who is the author of the short story "In a Grove," which was later adapted into the film "Rashomon"?
What is the term used to describe a situation in which individuals give significantly different but equally conceivable accounts of the same event?
Under what two conditions does the Rashomon effect usually occur?

options.label: A
options.text: When there is evidence to verify what really happened and no pressure to achieve closure

options.label: B
options.text: When there is no evidence to verify what really happened and no pressure to achieve closure

options.label: C
options.text: When there is evidence to verify what really happened and pressure to achieve closure

options.label: D
options.text: When there is no evidence to verify what really happened and pressure to achieve closure

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the phenomenon where people subconsciously reshape their memories in ways that cast a positive light on their actions?
According to neuroscientists, what happens to a memory when we recall it?

options.label: C
options.text: It incorporates new information that changes the memory

multiple-choice.question: In what field do scientists often experience the Rashomon effect, where they start from the same dataset and apply the same analytical methods but publish different results?
What is the name of the Mexican village where two anthropologists visited and recorded different perceptions of the residents?
What event in 2015 is cited as an example of the Rashomon effect, where media reports varied enormously?

options.label: A
options.text: A security summit between the United States and leaders from the Arab States

multiple-choice.question: What is the main question raised by the Rashomon effect, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Why do people have competing perceptions?

options.label: C
options.text: How can we make group decisions?

options.label: D
options.text: What is the importance of objective truth?

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the value of embracing the ambiguity raised by the Rashomon effect?

options.label: A
options.text: It leads to a definitive answer

options.label: B
options.text: It highlights the importance of objective truth

options.label: C
options.text: It suggests that there may be value in embracing the ambiguity

options.label: D
options.text: It undermines the idea of a singular, objective truth

title: Can you be awake and asleep at the same time? - Masako Tamaki

multiple-choice.question: What type of sleep do some animals, including birds and mammals, experience where parts of their brain are asleep and other areas are more active?
Which of the following is a characteristic of unihemispheric sleep?

options.label: A
options.text: Both brain hemispheres are in deep sleep

options.label: B
options.text: One brain hemisphere is in deep sleep, and the other is completely awake

options.label: C
options.text: Both brain hemispheres are in light sleep

options.label: D
options.text: One brain hemisphere is in light sleep, and the other is in REM sleep

multiple-choice.question: Why do dolphins sleep unihemispherically?

options.label: B
options.text: To stay alert to threats from the depths

options.label: C
options.text: To continue swimming and breathing while snoozing

multiple-choice.question: How do fur seals sleep while migrating at sea?

options.label: A
options.text: They sleep with both hemispheres at a time

options.label: B
options.text: They sleep with one hemisphere at a time, floating horizontally

options.label: C
options.text: They sleep with one hemisphere at a time, floating vertically

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the way mallard ducks sleep in groups?

options.label: A
options.text: They all sleep with both hemispheres at a time

options.label: B
options.text: They all sleep with one hemisphere at a time

options.label: C
options.text: Ducks on the peripheries spend more time in unihemispheric sleep

options.label: D
options.text: Ducks in the center spend more time in unihemispheric sleep

multiple-choice.question: How do frigatebirds sleep during non-stop transoceanic flights?

options.label: A
options.text: They sleep with both hemispheres at a time

options.label: B
options.text: They sleep with one hemisphere at a time

options.label: C
options.text: They sleep in seconds-long bursts, usually while riding air currents

multiple-choice.question: What is currently unclear about asymmetrical sleep?

options.label: A
options.text: Whether it is more restorative than sleep in both hemispheres

options.label: B
options.text: Whether it is less restorative than sleep in both hemispheres

options.label: C
options.text: Whether it packs the same benefits as sleep in both hemispheres

options.label: D
options.text: Whether it is only experienced by marine mammals

multiple-choice.question: What did an experiment with fur seals suggest about asymmetrical sleep?

options.label: A
options.text: It is more restorative than sleep in both hemispheres

options.label: B
options.text: It is less restorative than sleep in both hemispheres

options.label: C
options.text: It is equally restorative as sleep in both hemispheres

options.label: D
options.text: It is only necessary for marine mammals

multiple-choice.question: What is the "first night effect" in humans?

options.label: C
options.text: A subtle version of asymmetrical sleep

multiple-choice.question: Why do humans use asymmetrical sleep, according to the transcript?

options.label: B
options.text: To stay alert to threats from the environment

title: What’s in the air you breathe? - Amy Hrdina and Jesse Kroll

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of Earth's atmosphere is composed of nitrogen?
What is the primary source of oxygen in Earth's atmosphere?
What percentage of the air we breathe is made up of dry gases such as nitrogen, oxygen, and argon?
What is the name of the type of smog formed by the reaction of sulfur oxides with oxygen and water vapor?
What is the primary cause of photochemical smog?

options.label: A
options.text: Burning of fossil fuels by vehicles

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of catalytic converters in vehicles?

options.label: B
options.text: To reduce emissions of carbon monoxide and nitrogen oxides

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the air we breathe is made up of man-made pollutants?
What is the name of the type of pollutants that are directly emitted from a source?
What is the effect of sulfurous smog on human health?

options.label: B
options.text: It impairs visibility and causes severe lung damage

multiple-choice.question: Why is there no universal remedy for air pollution?

options.label: A
options.text: Because different regions have different pollutants

options.label: B
options.text: Because air pollution is a natural phenomenon

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is too expensive to implement

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a global problem

title: Why good ideas get trapped in the valley of death— and how to rescue them

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the phase where new products must pass through before they reach the market, and many never make it out?
Which type of innovations are especially at risk in the valley of death?
What is a major reason why good ideas get trapped in the valley of death?
Why are zero-carbon technologies particularly vulnerable in the valley of death?

options.label: B
options.text: They have short timelines to profitability

options.label: C
options.text: They require big changes in infrastructure and consumer behavior

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a zero-carbon technology that can remove CO2 directly from the atmosphere?
What creates a vicious cycle for zero-carbon technologies in the valley of death?

options.label: A
options.text: High initial costs and low market demand

options.label: B
options.text: Low initial costs and high market demand

options.label: C
options.text: High initial costs scaring off investors

multiple-choice.question: How can governments help close the funding gap for zero-carbon technologies?

options.label: B
options.text: By providing tax incentives and loans

options.label: C
options.text: By reducing research and development spending

options.label: D
options.text: By imposing carbon taxes on consumers

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of government initiatives to support the development of solar panels in the 1990s?

options.label: A
options.text: The cost of solar panels increased

options.label: B
options.text: The adoption of solar panels decreased

options.label: C
options.text: The cost of solar panels dropped almost 90% since 2009

options.label: D
options.text: The development of solar panels was halted

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a government initiative that can help shape policies and markets to support zero-carbon technologies?

options.label: C
options.text: Offering tax and loan incentives to startups

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is necessary for ideas and inventions to solve our most daunting problems?

options.label: A
options.text: Policies and markets must be shaped to support them

options.label: B
options.text: They must be developed without government support

options.label: C
options.text: They must be funded solely by private investors

options.label: D
options.text: They must be developed without considering market demand

title: Why every world map is wrong - Kayla Wolf

multiple-choice.question: What is a major limitation of creating a flat map of the world?

options.label: A
options.text: The Earth's geography is constantly changing.

options.label: B
options.text: The Earth is too large to be mapped accurately.

options.label: C
options.text: It's impossible to make a 100% accurate flat map of a spherical planet.

options.label: D
options.text: The Earth's climate varies greatly from one region to another.

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with systematically mapping the Earth on a grid using coordinates?
What is the name of the map projection created by Gerardus Mercator in 1569?
What is a major drawback of the Mercator Projection?

options.label: A
options.text: It is not useful for navigation.

options.label: B
options.text: It distorts land masses and bodies of water, making those near the equator appear smaller.

options.label: C
options.text: It is not widely used today.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not suitable for online maps.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the map projection created in 1925 to minimize distortion for the entire world?
Who designed the AuthaGraph World Map, considered the most accurate projection to date?
What is a criticism of the Mercator Projection made by Arno Peters?

options.label: A
options.text: It is not useful for navigation.

options.label: B
options.text: It gives white nations a sense of supremacy over non-white nations by enlarging European and North American countries.

options.label: C
options.text: It is not widely used today.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not suitable for online maps.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the map projection adapted by Arno Peters to counteract the problem of the Mercator Projection?
Why do maps still play a vital role in education, despite being used less for navigation?

options.label: A
options.text: They provide accurate information about the world's geography.

options.label: B
options.text: They shape our perception of the world and tell a story from the perspective of the map's creator.

options.label: C
options.text: They are useful for online navigation.

options.label: D
options.text: They are a relic of the past.

multiple-choice.question: What is a consequence of simple changes in map design?

options.label: A
options.text: They can make the map more accurate.

options.label: B
options.text: They can make the map more visually appealing.

options.label: C
options.text: They can completely shift our point of view and shape our perception of the world.

options.label: D

title: How much electricity does it take to power the world?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary source of energy that powers the turbine in an electric power plant?
What unit of measurement is typically used to express the amount of electricity used to power something?
Approximately how many watts are required to power a small town?

What percentage increase in electricity demand is expected by 2050 due to industrialization and population growth?
What is the primary reason for the need to switch from fossil fuels to electric power in various industries?
What fraction of the world's electricity is currently generated from clean energy sources?
What is the main challenge associated with using wind and solar power as primary sources of energy?

options.label: C
options.text: Difficulty in storing and transporting energy

multiple-choice.question: What is nuclear fusion, and how does it generate energy?

options.label: A
options.text: It involves splitting heavy atoms to release energy

options.label: B
options.text: It involves smashing light atoms together to release energy

options.label: C
options.text: It involves burning fossil fuels to generate electricity

options.label: D
options.text: It involves harnessing energy from the sun and wind

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential impact of breakthroughs in clean energy technologies such as nuclear fusion, fission, solar, and wind power?

options.label: C
options.text: Enabling the world to sustain a tripled electricity supply

title: Why can't we talk about periods? - Jen Gunter

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's experience with menstruation like as a teenager?

options.label: A
options.text: She had light and manageable periods.

options.label: B
options.text: She had typical periods with some cramping.

options.label: C
options.text: She had terrible periods with crippling cramps, heavy bleeding, and period diarrhea.

options.label: D
options.text: She did not experience menstruation until her early twenties.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the speaker's doctor recommend she eat liver?

options.label: D
options.text: To treat her heavy periods, although the reason is not specified.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's argument about the stigma surrounding menstruation?

options.label: A
options.text: It's because of the blood and mess involved.

options.label: B
options.text: It's because of patriarchal society's investment in oppressing women.

options.label: C
options.text: It's because of the pain and discomfort associated with menstruation.

options.label: D
options.text: It's because of the inconvenience it causes.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the hormone progesterone in the menstrual cycle?

options.label: C
options.text: To prepare the uterus for implantation and hold the uterine lining together.

multiple-choice.question: Why can't the uterine lining just stay in the uterus until the next cycle?

options.label: B
options.text: Because it's too thick and can't be reabsorbed.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, why do humans have a thick uterine lining?

options.label: A
options.text: To support the growth of the embryo.

options.label: B
options.text: To prepare the uterus for implantation.

options.label: C
options.text: To maximize the chance of a beneficial outcome by making embryos work for it.

multiple-choice.question: How does the uterus stop bleeding during menstruation?

options.label: A
options.text: By releasing hormones to reduce blood flow.

options.label: B
options.text: By cramping down on the blood vessels to stop the bleeding.

options.label: D
options.text: By releasing more blood to flush out the uterus.

multiple-choice.question: What is the pressure generated in the uterus during menstruation comparable to?

options.label: A
options.text: The pressure of a blood pressure cuff.

options.label: B
options.text: The pressure during the first stage of labor.

options.label: C
options.text: The pressure during the second stage of labor when pushing.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way to address menstrual pain, according to the speaker?
According to the speaker, why is it essential to talk about menstruation and break the menstrual taboos?

options.label: C
options.text: To increase knowledge and understanding of the female body.

options.label: D
options.text: To encourage the use of hormonal contraception.

title: Using your voice is a political choice - Amanda Gorman

options.label: A
options.text: What do you stand for, and what do you stand on?

options.label: B
options.text: Who are your favorite poets, and what inspires you?

options.label: C
options.text: What is your favorite type of poetry, and why do you like it?

options.label: D
options.text: How do you write poetry, and what is your creative process?

options.text: "I am the daughter of white writers"

options.label: B
options.text: "I am the daughter of black writers who were descended from freedom fighters"

options.label: C
options.text: "I am a poet, and I am proud"

options.label: D
options.text: "I am a writer, and I am fearless"

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's main fear when it came to public speaking?

options.label: A
options.text: That she would forget her lines

options.label: B
options.text: That she would trip on stage

options.label: C
options.text: That her words would jumble and stumble due to her speech impediment

options.label: D
options.text: That she would be booed off stage

options.label: B
options.text: That she had a responsibility to speak up for those who couldn't

options.label: C
options.text: That if she chose not to speak out of fear, then there's no one that her silence is standing for

options.label: D
options.text: That public speaking was easy and fun

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker mean by "honorary ancestors"?

options.label: A
options.text: People who are related to her by blood or birth

options.label: C
options.text: People who have inspired her and are worth saying their names

options.label: D
options.text: People who are dead and gone

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what makes poetry powerful?

options.label: A
options.text: Its ability to rhyme and have a good beat

options.label: B
options.text: Its ability to tell stories that matter

options.label: C
options.text: Its ability to be read by anyone

options.label: D
options.text: Its ability to be written by anyone

multiple-choice.question: Why does the speaker think that poetry is political?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it's only written by politicians

options.label: B
options.text: Because it's only read by politicians

options.label: C
options.text: Because it has the power to connect the beliefs of the private individual with the cause of change of the public

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker mean by "poetry is at the pulse of the most dangerous and daring questions that a nation or world might face"?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: That poetry is only about answering questions

options.label: C
options.text: That poetry is about asking challenging and thought-provoking questions

options.label: D
options.text: That poetry is only about politics

options.label: B
options.text: Maya Angelou, Ozaki Shanghai, Phyllis Wheatley, and Lucille Clifton

options.label: C
options.text: Martin Luther King Jr., Malcolm X, and Nelson Mandela

options.label: D
options.text: Emily Dickinson, Robert Frost, and Walt Whitman

multiple-choice.question: What is the main message that the speaker wants to convey to her audience?

options.label: A
options.text: That poetry is only for certain people

options.label: B
options.text: That poetry is only about politics

options.label: C
options.text: That poetry has the power to inspire and bring about change

options.label: D
options.text: That poetry is only about rhyming and having a good beat

options.label: C
